questions.text: A 6-month-old boy presents with recurrent bacterial and fungal infections, chronic diarrhea, and failure to thrive. He is diagnosed with severe combined immunodeficiency due to an autosomal recessive inheritance pattern. Which enzyme deficiency is responsible?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Adenosine deaminase

Explanation:

The patient’s symptoms—recurrent bacterial and fungal infections, chronic diarrhea, and failure to thrive—are characteristic of Severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID). SCID is a condition where there is a severe deficiency in both T-cell and B-cell function, leading to an increased susceptibility to infections. One of the most common causes of SCID is a deficiency in adenosine deaminase (ADA), an enzyme involved in purine metabolism. A deficiency in ADA results in toxic accumulation of adenosine and deoxyadenosine, which primarily affects T-cells and B-cells, leading to immune dysfunction.

Phosphomannose isomerase (Option A): A deficiency in this enzyme leads to congenital disorders of glycosylation, which can present with developmental delay, but it is not associated with SCID.

Ornithine transcarbamylase (Option B): This enzyme deficiency leads to urea cycle disorders, specifically hyperammonemia, which does not cause SCID or the described immune symptoms.

Hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT) (Option C): A deficiency in HGPRT causes Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, characterized by neurological and behavioral problems, gout, and kidney stones, but not SCID.

questions.text: Which antibody is the first to appear and acts fastest during a primary (first) immune response to an infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) IgM

Explanation:

IgM is produced early by naïve B cells after first exposure to an antigen. It is a pentamer, so it has 10 antigen-binding sites, giving it very high avidity (strong total binding), which makes it effective even before affinity maturation occurs.
It activates the classical complement pathway efficiently, helping clear pathogens quickly.

IgG (Option B): Appears later in the primary response but dominates the secondary response due to memory B cells.
IgE (Option C): Mainly for allergic reactions and defense against parasites; not part of early general infection control.
IgA (Option D): Found in mucosal secretions (tears, saliva, breast milk) for local immunity; not the first systemic responder.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most potent stimulator of naïve T-cells ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A

  • Mature dendritic cells are the most potent stimulators of naïve T-cells. Dendritic cells are antigen-presenting cells (APCs) that play a critical role in initiating and regulating immune responses. They are found in various tissues and are particularly abundant in lymphoid organs.
  • When dendritic cells encounter antigens, such as microbial pathogens or tumor cells, they capture and process these antigens. Subsequently, they migrate to lymphoid organs, such as lymph nodes, where they present the processed antigens to naïve T-cells.
  • Mature dendritic cells express high levels of co-stimulatory molecules, such as CD80 and CD86, as well as major histocompatibility complex (MHC) molecules. These molecules are necessary for effective T-cell activation. When a naïve T-cell recognizes its specific antigen presented by a mature dendritic cell, a complex series of signaling events occur, leading to T-cell activation and proliferation.
  • The interaction between naïve T-cells and mature dendritic cells is crucial for initiating adaptive immune responses. It leads to the differentiation of naïve T-cells into effector T-cells, such as cytotoxic T-cells or helper T-cells, which carry out specific immune functions to eliminate the pathogen or mediate immune responses.

Incorrect Option:

Option B. Follicular dendritic cells: Follicular dendritic cells (FDCs) are specialized stromal cells found in lymphoid follicles, particularly in the germinal centers of lymph nodes. They play a crucial role in the organization of B-cell areas and the generation of antibody responses. While FDCs interact with B-cells, they are not the primary stimulators of naïve T-cells.

Option C. B lymphocytes: B lymphocytes, also known as B cells, are a type of white blood cell involved in humoral immune responses mediated by antibodies. B cells can present antigens to helper T-cells and receive signals from them for proper activation and differentiation. However, mature dendritic cells are generally considered more potent in stimulating naïve T-cells compared to B cells.

Option D. NK cells: Natural killer (NK) cells are a type of cytotoxic lymphocyte that plays a role in innate immune responses, particularly in the early defense against viral infections and tumor surveillance. NK cells are not primarily involved in the stimulation of naïve T-cells, as their main function is to directly recognize and kill infected or abnormal cells.

questions.text: What type of hypersensitivity reaction is implicated in the hyperacute rejection of kidney transplants?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Type II:

  • Hyperacute rejection of renal transplants involves a type II hypersensitivity reaction.
  • Type II hypersensitivity reactions are mediated by the binding of antibodies, typically IgM or IgG, to antigens on the surface of target cells or tissues.
  • In the case of hyperacute rejection, preformed antibodies in the recipient's blood react with antigens on the transplanted kidney, leading to immediate and severe destruction of the graft.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Type IV hypersensitivity reaction: Type IV hypersensitivity reactions, also known as delayed-type hypersensitivity reactions, are cell-mediated immune responses involving T cells. They are characterized by a delayed onset of symptoms, typically 24-48 hours after exposure to the antigen. Type IV hypersensitivity reactions are not involved in hyperacute rejection, which occurs rapidly after transplantation.

Option B - Type III hypersensitivity reaction: Type III hypersensitivity reactions involve the formation of immune complexes composed of antigens and antibodies, leading to tissue damage when deposited in various organs. These reactions typically occur several hours to days after exposure to the antigen. Hyperacute rejection of renal transplants is not primarily mediated by immune complex deposition, making type III hypersensitivity reaction an incorrect option.

Option D - Type I hypersensitivity reaction: Type I hypersensitivity reactions, also known as immediate hypersensitivity or allergic reactions, involve the release of histamine and other inflammatory mediators in response to an allergen. Type I hypersensitivity reactions are associated with conditions such as allergies, asthma, and anaphylaxis. They are not directly implicated in hyperacute rejection of renal transplants.

questions.text: Which of the following is a crucial element involved in activating the complement through the alternative pathway?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - C3:

Explanation:

  • The alternative pathway of complement activation is primarily initiated by the spontaneous hydrolysis of C3 to form C3(H2O), which then binds to factor B. This activates the pathway and leads to the formation of the C3 convertase, which plays a key role in the amplification of the complement cascade.
  • In the alternative pathway, C3 is crucial for both the activation and amplification of the complement system, as it is cleaved to form C3a and C3b, which further participate in opsonization, inflammation, and cell lysis.

Complement System:

  • Definition: A complex network of at least 30 proteins in the blood, crucial for innate and acquired immunity.
  • Functions:
    • Lysis: Directly kills pathogens by forming membrane pores.
    • Opsonization: Coats pathogens to enhance recognition and uptake by phagocytes.
    • Immune Clearance: Removes immune complexes from circulation.
    • Inflammation: Triggers release of mediators, recruiting immune cells.

Pathways of Complement Activation:

Pathway

Trigger Mechanism

Key Components Involved

Classical Pathway

Binding of C1q to antigen-antibody complexes

C1q (Option A ruled out), C3 convertase, Membrane Attack Complex (MAC)

Alternative Pathway

Direct binding of complement proteins to pathogens

C3, factors B and D, C3 convertase

Lectin Pathway

Binding of mannose-binding lectin (MBL) to mannose

MBL, MASP1, MASP2, C4 (Option D ruled out), C2 (Option B ruled out), C3 convertase

Key Points:

  • Convergence: All pathways converge at the formation of the C3 convertase.
  • C3 Convertase: Cleaves C3 into C3a and C3b, leading to the formation of C5 convertase and, ultimately, MAC.
  • Regulation: The complement system is tightly regulated to prevent excessive activation and damage to host tissues.
  • Regulatory Proteins: Include inhibitors and inactivators that control the cascade.

questions.text: Identify the class of immunoglobulin shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) IgA

Explanation:

The image shows dimeric IgA, which is characterized by:

  • Two IgA monomers linked by a J chain
  • Secretory component that protects it from enzymatic degradation in mucosal surfaces

IgA:

  • Two types – IgA1 and IgA2
  • Major immunoglobulin in colostrum, saliva, and tears
  • Two Forms: Monomeric serum IgA and dimeric secretory IgA
  • Secretory IgA:
    • Two monomer units joined together at their carboxy terminals by a glycopeptide termed the J chain
    • Produced by plasma cells near mucosal or glandular epithelium
    • Secretory piece or secretory component in the IgA protects IgA from bacterial proteases, especially in areas with abundant bacterial flora (e.g., intestines)
    • Role in Local Immunity: Concentrated in secretions, it forms an "antibody paste" on mucosal surfaces to protect against respiratory and intestinal pathogens.
    • Resistance: Relatively resistant to digestive enzymes and reducing agents
    • Activates the alternative complement pathway

IgG (Option B): The most abundant antibody in circulation

  • Monomeric in structure (no J chain or secretory component).
  • Involved in long-term immunity, opsonization, and complement activation.

IgM (Option C): Exists as a pentamer in serum with a J chain and is efficient in complement activation and agglutination.

IgE (Option D):

  • Heat-labile (sensitive to heat)
  • It has an affinity for the surface of tissue cells (particularly mast cells) of the same species (homocytotropism)
  • Mediates Prausnitz-Küstner Reaction
  • Distribution: Primarily found in extravascular spaces
  • Elevated Levels: In atopic conditions (type I allergies) like asthma, hay fever, eczema, and parasitic infections
  • Function: Protects against pathogens by triggering mast cell degranulation and releasing inflammatory mediators

IgD:

  • IgD and IgM occur on the surface of unstimulated B lymphocytes
  • Function:
    • Acts as recognition receptors for antigens
    • It causes specific stimulation of the B cell - either activation or cloning, to produce antibodies or suppression.

questions.text: Which of the following is the enzyme conjugate in the given ELISA technique?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) II

Explanation:

  • The given image is of Sandwich ELISA, which detects antigens in a patient's sample by sandwiching the antigen between two antibodies
  • In Sandwich ELISA, the enzyme conjugate is typically an enzyme-linked secondary antibody that binds to the captured antigen. Here’s how the components work:
    • I - This represents the substrate (e.g., TMB for HRP), which reacts with the enzyme to produce a colorimetric signal.
    • II - This represents the enzyme-conjugated detection antibody, which binds to the antigen in a sandwich manner. The enzyme later catalyzes a reaction to produce a detectable signal.
    • III - This indicates the antigen, which is sandwiched between the capture and detection antibodies.
    • IV - This represents the capture antibody

questions.text: Type IV hypersensitivity is due to which of the following mechanisms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Cell-mediated response

Explanation:

  • Type IV hypersensitivity, also known as delayed-type hypersensitivity (DTH), is primarily mediated by T cells, not antibodies.
  • It involves the activation of T lymphocytes that release cytokines, leading to inflammation and tissue damage. The response is delayed, typically occurring 48-72 hours after exposure to the antigen.

Types of hypersensitivity reactions and their features:

Hours to days

Delayed (hours to days)

T-cell mediated response

Skin rash, contact dermatitis

Cell-mediated and antibody-mediated response (Option B):

  • This option describes a scenario that is more characteristic of Type III hypersensitivity, which involves both immune complexes (antibody-antigen complexes) and cell-mediated responses.

 

Antibody-mediated response (Option C):

  • Type II and Type III hypersensitivity are antibody-mediated responses.
  • In Type II, antibodies (IgG or IgM) bind to cell surface antigens, causing complement activation or cell destruction.
  • In Type III, antibodies form immune complexes that deposit in tissues, leading to inflammation.

 

Innate response (Option D):

  • The innate immune response involves components like macrophages, neutrophils, and dendritic cells, but Type IV hypersensitivity is specifically a T-cell mediated adaptive immune response.

questions.text: Affinity maturation is due to:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Somatic hypermutation

Explanation:

  • Affinity maturation is a process where B cells undergo somatic hypermutation in germinal centers, leading to the production of antibodies with higher affinity for the antigen.
  • This occurs after the initial IgM response, resulting in the production of IgG (or other classes) with enhanced specificity and effectiveness.

Antibody formation involves B cell activation upon encountering an antigen.

  • The initial response produces IgM, which can then undergo class switching to produce other antibody types like IgG, IgA, and IgE.
  • This process is crucial for mounting an effective immune response against pathogens, with IgG being the most abundant antibody in serum and providing long-term immunity.

The formation of antibodies, or immunoglobulins involves multiple cellular components and steps:

  1. Antigen Encounter and Recognition
    • The process begins when B cells encounter a specific antigen. This antigen must be recognized as foreign to activate the adaptive immune response.
    • B cell receptors (BCRs) on the surface of B cells bind to the antigen. This recognition is highly specific and depends on the unique variable regions of the immunoglobulin on BCRs.
  2. Activation of B Cells
    • Upon binding with the antigen, B cells become activated, which requires help from T helper (Th) cells.
    • T cells are required to release cytokines and co-stimulatory signals, which aid in the full activation of B cells, especially in the case of protein antigens.
  3. Proliferation and Clonal Expansion
    • Activated B cells undergo clonal expansion, where they proliferate to create identical cells that can produce the same specific antibody.
    • This clonal expansion amplifies the immune response, ensuring that a sufficient number of cells are available to target the pathogen.
  4. Differentiation into Plasma Cells and Memory B Cells
    • Following expansion, B cells differentiate into two main cell types:
      • Plasma Cells: These are the effector cells that actively secrete antibodies. Plasma cells are responsible for producing large quantities of antibodies, which are then released into the bloodstream.
      • Memory B Cells: These cells are long-lived and retain the memory of the specific antigen. Upon subsequent exposure to the same antigen, memory B cells can quickly initiate a secondary immune response, leading to a faster and more robust production of antibodies.
  5. Antibody Class Switching
    • Initially, B cells produce IgM antibodies. However, with the help of Th cells, B cells can undergo a process called "class switching" to produce other types of antibodies like IgG, IgA, or IgE.
    • Class switching allows the immune system to adapt the type of antibody produced to the specific requirements of the immune response, depending on the nature of the pathogen and the location of the infection.
  6. Affinity Maturation
    • Affinity maturation occurs in the germinal centers of lymphoid tissues and involves the somatic hypermutation of antibody genes.
    • This process leads to the production of antibodies with increased affinity for the antigen, allowing for a more effective immune response.
  7. Memory and Long-Term Immunity
    • Memory B cells generated during the primary response ensure long-term immunity. If the same antigen is encountered again, these cells quickly respond by differentiating into plasma cells and producing antibodies.
    • This secondary immune response is usually faster and more intense due to the Spresence of these memory cells.

 

Incorrect Options:

Isotype switching (Option A): Isotype (class) switching alters the constant region of the antibody (e.g., IgM → IgG, IgA, or IgE) without affecting antigen specificity. It allows adaptation of antibody function but does not directly enhance antigen affinity.

mRNA splicing (Option C): This process regulates antibody expression (e.g., membrane-bound vs. secreted forms of immunoglobulins) but does not enhance antigen affinity.

VDJ rearrangement (Option D): This occurs during B cell development in the bone marrow, generating primary antibody diversity. However, it is not responsible for post-activation affinity maturation.

questions.solution:
• Type 4 hypersensitivity reaction is cell-mediated, and the characteristic cells called TDTH cells (delayed type of hypersensitivity T cells) are the principal mediators of type IV reactions.
  • The antigen-presenting cells process and present the antigenic peptides along with MHC-II to the helper T cells. TH cells are differentiated to form TDTH cells.

Macrophage (Option B) In type 4 hypersensitivity reaction, macrophages are activated as an endpoint of the reaction but are mediated through T cell activation.

Dendritic cells (Option C) They are the macrophages found in the epidermis and act as APCs. They have large dendritic projections used for capturing various pathogens.

Neutrophils (Option D) They are primary immune cells and act as first-response cells during acute inflammation. They are not involved in hypersensitivity reactions.

questions.text: Besides NK cells, what other types of cells are capable of identifying and lysing target cells that have specific antibody-bound membrane surface antigens as part of their effector mechanisms in cell-mediated immunity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Neutrophils and eosinophils

Explanation:

Antibody-dependent Cellular Cytotoxicity (ADCC)

  • Neutrophils
  • Macrophages
  • Eosinophils
  • NK cells
  • Mechanism: IgG antibodies bind to target cells via the Fab region, while the Fc region binds to Fc receptors on effector cells (e.g., NK cells), leading to target cell destruction.
  • Target: ADCC targets cells that are too large for phagocytosis, such as parasites, tumor cells, or transplanted tissue.
  • Antibody Types: Primarily mediated by IgG antibodies; in some cases, such as eosinophil-mediated killing of parasites, IgE antibodies are involved.

Basophils are primarily involved in allergic responses and do not play a role in ADCC.

questions.text: CD4 T-cell activation is done by?
questions.solution:
CD4 T-cell activation is done by MHC II.

 

Feature

MHC Class II

Found on almost all nucleated cells

Found mainly on antigen-presenting cells (APCs) such as macrophages, dendritic cells, and B-cells

Antigen Source

Presents intracellular antigens (e.g., viral or tumor proteins)

Presents extracellular antigens (e.g., bacterial peptides)

Interacts With

CD8+ T-cells (cytotoxic T-cells)

CD4+ T-cells (helper T-cells)

Main HLA Genes

HLA-A, HLA-B, HLA-C

HLA-DP, HLA-DQ, HLA-DR

Structure

Consists of one α (heavy) chain and β2-microglobulin;

peptide-binding groove formed by α1 and α2

Consists of α and β chains; peptide-binding groove formed by α1 and β1 domains

Function

The antigen is presented by MHC Class I molecules to CD8+ T-cells, leading to cytotoxic T-cell-mediated destruction (Option A): MHC Class I molecules present intracellular antigens to CD8+ T-cells, not CD4+ T-cells. MHC I is not primarily involved in antibody-mediated autoimmune diseases like myasthenia gravis, which involve MHC Class II.

 

MHC Class I molecules are found only on professional antigen-presenting cells, which present the antigen to helper T-cells (Option C): MHC Class I molecules are found on all nucleated cells, not just APCs. Additionally, MHC I interacts with CD8+ T-cells rather than helper T-cells (CD4+). The statement here mischaracterizes both the distribution and the function of MHC Class I molecules.

 

MHC Class II molecules are present on all nucleated cells and help in presenting intracellular antigens (Option D): MHC Class II is restricted to antigen-presenting cells, not all nucleated cells, and presents extracellular antigens, not intracellular ones. In autoimmune reactions, extracellular antigens are generally presented by MHC II to CD4+ T-cells, which is key to the autoantibody production pathway in myasthenia gravis.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the ED after being stung by a bee while playing outside. Within minutes of the sting, he developed shock, respiratory failure, and vascular collapse. What type of hypersensitivity reaction is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) IgE-mediated reaction

Explanation: The symptoms described—shock, respiratory failure, and vascular collapse—occur within minutes of a bee sting, which is a classic presentation of an allergic reaction triggered by IgE-mediated hypersensitivity (also known as Type I hypersensitivity). This reaction is commonly referred to as anaphylaxis.

  • Type I Hypersensitivity (Early), is an immediate reaction triggered by IgE-mediated mast cell degranulation, causing symptoms like hives, swelling, and respiratory distress within minutes of allergen exposure.
  • Other options describe features inconsistent with her presentation and typical of delayed hypersensitivity types (I (Delayed), III, and IV), which have different mechanisms and symptom timelines.

Type I hypersensitivity reaction phases and its features:

Phase

Timing

Mechanism

Clinical Features

Early Phase

Seconds to minutes

Mast cell/basophil degranulation: IgE cross-linking leads to the release of histamine and other mediators.

Skin: Urticaria (hives), itching (pruritus), erythema (redness), localized angioedema (swelling around lips, eyes)

Respiratory: Bronchoconstriction leading to wheezing, shortness of breath, chest tightness, sneezing, nasal congestion (allergic rhinitis)

Cardiovascular: Vasodilation and hypotension (drop in blood pressure), dizziness, syncope (fainting)

Gastrointestinal: Nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, diarrhea due to smooth muscle contraction

Systemic Reaction: Anaphylaxis in severe cases, with generalized urticaria, angioedema, severe hypotension, and respiratory distress (life-threatening)

Late Phase

4–12 hours, peaks at 24–48 hours, lasting up to days

Inflammatory cell recruitment: Cytokines/chemokines attract eosinophils, neutrophils, and macrophages, causing sustained inflammation.

Skin: Persistent redness, swelling, intense itching, and development of an eczema-like rash (seen in atopic dermatitis)

Respiratory: Recurrent bronchoconstriction, prolonged wheezing, coughing, chest tightness, mucus production, and airway hyperresponsiveness (chronic asthma exacerbation)

Eyes: Persistent redness and irritation in conjunctiva (allergic conjunctivitis)

Chronic Changes: In prolonged or recurrent reactions, there may be tissue remodeling, fibrosis, and thickening of affected areas (e.g., airways in asthma, skin in chronic dermatitis)

IgG-mediated reaction (Option A): This is typical of Type II hypersensitivity reactions (such as hemolytic anemia), which involve antibody binding to antigens on cells or tissues, leading to cell destruction. It is not associated with anaphylaxis.

IgA-mediated hypersensitivity (Option B): This is involved in Type III hypersensitivity (e.g., in conditions like immune complex disease), where antibody-antigen complexes form and cause inflammation, but it is not the cause of anaphylaxis.

questions.text: Which blood is transfused in a patient with a Bombay blood group?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) O negative

Explanation:

  • The Bombay blood group (hh) is a rare blood type in which the individual lacks the H antigen, which is a precursor for the A and B antigens on red blood cells. This means that a person with the Bombay blood group cannot receive blood from individuals with the typical ABO blood groups (A, B, AB, or O) since their immune system will recognize the A, B, and H antigens as foreign and mount an immune response.
  • Because of this, only O negative blood (which lacks A, B, and H antigens) is compatible for transfusion to a person with the Bombay blood group.

Incorrect Options:

A, B, and AB blood (Option A, B, & C): These all contain the A, B, or both antigens, which a person with the Bombay blood group would react against due to the absence of the H antigen, leading to severe transfusion reactions.

questions.text: A person is found to have an absence of the CD40 marker. Which of the following would be seen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Absent B cells

Explanation:

CD40 Characteristics:

  • A TNF receptor family member expressed on B cells, APCs, non-immune cells, and tumors, which is an essential costimulatory marker.
  • Binds CD40L, which is transiently expressed on T cells and inflamed non-immune cells.
  • It interacts with CD40L on T helper cells, which is crucial for B cell activation, proliferation, and class switching.
  • If CD40 is absent, B cells cannot receive activation signals, leading to defective antibody production and absent/malfunctional B cells.
  • This condition is associated with Hyper-IgM Syndrome, an immunodeficiency disorder where B cells fail to undergo class switching due to defective CD40 signaling.

Absent T cells (Option A): T cells are present but fail to provide effective help to B cells due to impaired CD40-CD40L interaction.

NK cells do not rely on CD40 for their development.

Absent Macrophages (Option D): Macrophages are present but show impaired activation, leading to decreased IL-12 production and defective T-cell-mediated immunity.

questions.text: Penicillin was given to the patient and immune hemolytic anemia develops. Which type of hypersensitivity reaction is this?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Type 2

  • Type 2 hypersensitivity reaction, also known as cytotoxic hypersensitivity, involves the activation of the immune system against specific cells or tissues. In this case, penicillin can induce the production of antibodies that bind to the patient's own red blood cells, causing them to be targeted and destroyed by the immune system. This is what happens in immune hemolytic anemia.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Type 1: Type 1 hypersensitivity reaction involves the release of histamine and other inflammatory mediators from mast cells and basophils. This leads to immediate allergic reactions, such as hay fever, asthma, and anaphylaxis. It is not associated with immune hemolytic anemia.

Option C - Type 3: Type 3 hypersensitivity reaction occurs when immune complexes (antigen-antibody complexes) deposit in various tissues, leading to inflammation and tissue damage. This is typically seen in diseases like systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) or certain types of vasculitis. It is not directly associated with immune hemolytic anemia.

Option D - Type 4: Type 4 hypersensitivity reaction is a delayed-type hypersensitivity involving T cells and macrophages. It's associated with cell-mediated immune responses, such as contact dermatitis or granulomatous inflammation. This type of reaction is not directly related to immune hemolytic anemia caused by penicillin.

questions.text: Identify the class of immunoglobulin shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Ig A

Explanation:

IgA:

  • Two types – IgA1 and IgA2
  • Major immunoglobulin in colostrum, saliva, and tears
  • Two Forms: Monomeric serum IgA and dimeric secretory IgA
  • Secretory IgA:
    • Two monomer units joined together at their carboxy terminals by a glycopeptide termed the J chain
    • Produced by plasma cells near mucosal or glandular epithelium
    • Secretory piece or secretory component in the IgA protects IgA from bacterial proteases, especially in areas with abundant bacterial flora (e.g., intestines)
    • Role in Local Immunity: Concentrated in secretions, it forms an "antibody paste" on mucosal surfaces to protect against respiratory and intestinal pathogens.
    • Resistance: Relatively resistant to digestive enzymes and reducing agents
    • Activates the alternative complement pathway

IgG (Option B) Each subunit of IgG consists of two heavy chains (alpha chains) and two light chains (kappa or lambda chains) connected by disulfide bonds.

IgM (Option C) can be monomeric (when present as a membrane-bound antibody on B cells) or pentameric (secreted) in nature, i.e., five IgM monomeric units are joined with each other by a J chain to form a complete IgM pentamer having 10 Fab regions and 10 valencies.

IgE (Option D) Each subunit of IgE consists of two heavy chains (alpha chains) and two light chains (kappa or lambda chains) connected by disulfide bonds.

Immunoglobulin Functions:

  • IgG: Protects body fluids and gives long term immunity
  • IgA: Protects body and mucosal surfaces
  • IgM: First antibody produced in acute infection
  • IgE: Mediates allergic hypersensitivity
  • IgD: Present on the surface of B lymphocytes

questions.text: Which of the following immunoglobulins shows the highest concentration in serum?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) lgG

Explanation:

  • IgG is the most abundant immunoglobulin in human serum, constituting about 70-75% of the total immunoglobulin in the bloodstream. It plays a crucial role in the body's immune response by neutralizing toxins, opsonizing pathogens, and activating the complement system.

 

IgG

  • Four types – IgG1, IgG2, IgG3, and IgG4
  • It is the main serum immunoglobulin, constituting 80% of total serum antibodies
  • Distribution: Both intravascular and extravascular
  • Only maternal antibody transported across the placenta, providing passive immunity to newborns mop
  • Function:
    • Binds to microorganisms, enhancing their phagocytosis
    • Participates in complement fixation, precipitation, and neutralisation of toxins/viruses
    • Part of chronic inflammation
  • Clinical Application: Used in isoimmunisation for Rh-negative mothers with anti-Rh(D) IgG during delivery.

 

IgM

  • It is a heavy molecule, hence called 'the millionaire molecule.’
  • Structure: Made of five four-peptide subunits; requires a J chain for polymerisation
  • Valency: 10
  • Distribution: Primarily intravascular (80% of IgM)
  • Early Production: First antibody synthesized by the fetus, starting around 20 weeks of gestation
  • Short-Lived: IgM antibodies degrade sooner than IgG
  • Immune Hemolysis: One IgM molecule can induce hemolysis, unlike IgG, which requires 1,000 molecules for similar effect
  • Opsonization Efficiency: 500-1,000 times more effective in opsonization than IgG
  • This is the first antibody produced during an initial immune response, but its concentration in serum is lower than IgG. It is typically the first to respond to infections. (Option B ruled out)

 

IgA:

  • Two types – IgA1 and IgA2
  • Major immunoglobulin in colostrum, saliva, and tears
  • Two Forms: Monomeric serum IgA and dimeric secretory IgA
  • Found primarily in mucosal areas (like respiratory and gastrointestinal tracts), IgA is not present in the highest concentration in serum compared to IgG. (Option C ruled out)
  • Secretory IgA:
    • Two monomer units joined together at their carboxy terminals by a glycopeptide termed the J chain
    • Produced by plasma cells near mucosal or glandular epithelium
    • Secretory piece or secretory component in the IgA protects IgA from bacterial proteases, especially in areas with abundant bacterial flora (e.g., intestines)
    • Role in Local Immunity: Concentrated in secretions, it forms an "antibody paste" on mucosal surfaces to protect against respiratory and intestinal pathogens.
    • Resistance: Relatively resistant to digestive enzymes and reducing agents
    • Activates the alternative complement pathway

 

IgD:

  • IgD and IgM occur on the surface of unstimulated B lymphocytes
  • Function:
    • Acts as recognition receptors for antigens
    • It causes specific stimulation of the B cell - either activation or cloning, to produce antibodies or suppression.

 

IgE:

  • Heat-labile (sensitive to heat)
  • It has an affinity for the surface of tissue cells (particularly mast cells) of the same species (homocytotropism)
  • Mediates Prausnitz-Küstner Reaction
  • Distribution: Primarily found in extravascular spaces
  • Elevated Levels: In atopic conditions (type I allergies) like asthma, hay fever, eczema, and parasitic infections
  • Function: Protects against pathogens by triggering mast cell degranulation and releasing inflammatory mediators
  • This is present in very low concentrations in serum. It is primarily associated with allergic reactions and parasitic infections. (Option D ruled out)

 

Immunoglobulin Functions:

  • IgG: Protects body fluids
  • IgA: Protects body surfaces
  • IgM: Guards the bloodstream
  • IgE: Mediates allergic hypersensitivity
  • IgD: Present on the surface of B lymphocytes

questions.text: In which of the following disorders is vaccination not contraindicated?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Complement deficiency

Explanation:

  • Complement deficiencies primarily impair the humoral immune response.
  • However, patients have normal T-cell function, making both live and inactivated vaccines safe.
  • Vaccination against meningococcal and pneumococcal infections are strongly recommended.

DiGeorge syndrome (Option A):

  • DiGeorge syndrome is characterized by thymic hypoplasia, leading to T-cell deficiency.
  • Live vaccines are contraindicated in patients with severe T-cell deficiency due to the risk of vaccine-induced infection.
  • However, in mild cases with adequate T-cell function, some live vaccines may be considered under specialist guidance.

Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (Option B):

  • Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (WAS) is a combined B and T cell immunodeficiency, increasing susceptibility to infections.
  • Live vaccines are generally avoided due to impaired immune responses and the risk of vaccine-strain infection.
  • Patients with WAS may receive inactivated vaccines.

Ataxia-telangiectasia (Option D):

  • Ataxia-telangiectasia is a DNA repair disorder associated with immunodeficiency, particularly affecting IgA and T-cell function.
  • Live vaccines are generally avoided due to impaired cellular immunity, which increases the risk of adverse effects from attenuated pathogens.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for an 11-year-old boy who presented at the pediatric outpatient department with multiple abscesses on his face, chest, and back, along with a history of frequent respiratory infections. Uponexamination, the child showed signs of atopic excoriating skin and multiple cold abscesses on his back.
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Hyper IgE syndrome:

  • Hyper-IgE syndrome aka Job’s syndrome is a rare primary immunodeficiency disease characterized by eczema, recurrent staphylococcal skin abscesses, recurrent lung infections (pneumatocele), eosinophilia, and high serum levels of IgE.
  • The underlying mechanism is a defect in neutrophil chemotaxis due to mutations in either STAT3 or DOCK8 genes.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Hyper IgM syndrome: Hyper-IgM syndrome is an X-linked disorder characterized by increased recurrent sinopulmonary infections and diarrhea (reduced IgG), autoimmune hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, or neutropenia due to Increased IgM levels.

Option B - Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome: Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome is a rare X-linked immunodeficiency disorder characterized by eczema, recurrent infections, and thrombocytopenia (low platelet count).

Option D - Carcinoid syndrome: Carcinoid syndrome is a set of symptoms caused by carcinoid tumors, which are neuroendocrine tumors that produce excessive serotonin. The symptoms include flushing, diarrhea, bronchoconstriction, and cardiac abnormalities.

questions.text: Which of the following investigations does not involve the use of antibody labeling?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Hemagglutination Test:

  • The hemagglutination test is a technique used to detect certain viral or bacterial infections by observing the agglutination (clumping) of red blood cells (RBCs). In this test, the antigen of interest (usually a virus or bacteria) is mixed with RBCs (containing antibodies). If the antigen interacts with the antibodies in RBCs, it can cause them to clump together or agglutinate.
  • The hemagglutination test does not involve the use of labeled antibodies. Instead, it relies on the interaction between the antigen and the RBCs.
  • Examples of hemagglutination test are: Paul bunnel test (for EBV), Coomb’s test, and cold agglutination test for mycoplasma.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D are incorrect. These tests require labeled antibody to detect the presence of antigens.

questions.text: In the case of a 3-year-old child with a history of recurrent sinopulmonary infections caused by encapsulated organisms, which of the following is the most probable deficiency?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - IgG2:

  • IgG2 deficiency is associated with an increased susceptibility to infections caused by encapsulated bacteria. IgG2 plays a crucial role in opsonization, which is the process of tagging pathogens for destruction by phagocytes. It facilitates the phagocytosis of encapsulated bacteria by immune cells, leading to their elimination.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - IgG1: IgG1 is important for opsonization and immune response against protein antigens. While a deficiency in IgG1 can increase susceptibility to certain infections, it is not specifically associated with an increased susceptibility to encapsulated bacterial infections.

Option C - IgG3: IgG3 is an important antibody subclass involved in complement activation and immune response against certain bacterial pathogens.

Option D - IgG4: IgG4 is involved in immune tolerance and is associated with allergic responses and autoimmune conditions.

questions.text: Due to the lack of ________________, nude mice do not exhibit resistance to xenografts.
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - T Cell:

  • T cells are another type of lymphocyte that are essential for cell-mediated immunity.
  • They play a central role in recognizing and eliminating foreign antigens.
  • Nude mice(lack body hair), which lack functional T cells due to absence of thymus, are unable to mount an effective cell-mediated immune response.
  • Therefore, the absence of T cells is the primary reason for the lack of resistance to xenografts in nude mice.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option B for an explanation.

questions.text: The classical complement pathway is activated by the binding of ............... ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Ag-Ab complex:

  • The classical pathway is one of the three pathways that activate the complement system, an important part of the immune response. The classical pathway is primarily activated by the formation of antigen-antibody (Ag-Ab) complexes.
  • The first step is the binding of C1 to the antigen-antibody complex. The recognition unit of C1 is C1 q, which reacts with the Fc piece of bound lgM or IgG, leading to activation of the classical complement pathway.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - C1: C1 is a component of the complement system and is involved in the activation of the classical pathway. However, C1 is not the specific activator of the classical pathway; it requires binding to Ag-Ab complexes to initiate the pathway.

Option B - C3 convertase: C3 convertase is an enzyme involved in the cleavage of complement component C3 into its active forms. While C3 convertase is an important component in the complement system, it is not the activator of the classical pathway.

Option C - lgA: Classical complement pathway is activated by the IgG and IgM class of antibody, not IgA.

questions.text: Deficiency of which complement system increases the risk of N. meningitidis infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - C5-C9 deficiency:

  • Neisseria meningitidis is a bacterium that can cause meningococcal meningitis. The complement system plays an important role in the immune response against N. meningitidis.
  • Deficiency of the complement components C5-C9, also known as the membrane attack complex (MAC), impairs the ability of the immune system to form the MAC and lyse bacterial cells and increases the susceptibility to infections caused by this bacterium.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - C1-C4 deficiency: Deficiencies in C1-C4 components of the complement system are associated with an increased susceptibility to immune complex-mediated diseases like systemic lupus eryhtematosus,and glomerulonephritis.

Option C - C3 deficiency: C3 deficiency is associated with an increased susceptibility to recurrent pyogenic infections.

Option D - C2 deficiency: C2 deficiency is associated with an increased risk of systemic lupus erythematosus and immune complex diseases.

questions.text: Which of the subsequent options triggers the classical complement cascade?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Ag - Ab complex:

  • The first step is the binding of C 1 to the antigen-antibody complex.
  • The recognition unit of C1 is C1q, which reacts with the Fc piece of bound IgM or IgG.
  • C1q has six combining sites. Effective activation occurs only when C 1 q is attached to immunoglobulins by at least two of its binding sites.
  • One molecule of IgM or two molecules of IgG can, therefore, initiate the process.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - C1: C1 is the first component of the classical complement pathway and is activated by binding to antigen-antibody complexes.

Option B - C3 convertase: C3 convertase is an enzyme complex formed during the activation of the complement system but does not specifically activate the classical pathway.

Option C - IgA: Immunoglobulin A (IgA) is an antibody isotype involved in mucosal immunity and is not directly involved in activating the classical complement pathway.

questions.text: If a patient's plasma contains elevated levels of interferon beta, it is indicative of a probable infection caused by...
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Virus:

  • Interferon beta is a type of interferon that is produced by cells in response to viral infections. Interferons are proteins that play a crucial role in the body's immune response against viral infections. They help to inhibit viral replication, activate immune cells, and enhance the overall antiviral defense mechanisms.
  • The elevated levels of interferon beta in the patient's plasma suggest that the patient is experiencing a viral infection.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Interferon beta shows antiviral activity.

questions.text: Which one of the options below represents a site that has immunological privilege?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Seminiferous tubule:

  • Immunological privilege refers to the ability of certain anatomical sites or tissues to exhibit reduced immune surveillance and regulation. These privileged sites are characterized by the presence of specialized mechanisms that protect them from immune-mediated damage or inflammation.
  • The seminiferous tubules, which are structures found in the testes, are considered immunologically privileged sites. They play a crucial role in the production of sperm cells. The seminiferous tubules are protected from immune responses because they are enclosed within the blood-testis barrier, a specialized structure formed by tight junctions between the cells lining the tubules.

Examples of immunologically privileged sites include:

  1. Eyes (e.g., the cornea, anterior chamber)
  2. Brain (due to the blood-brain barrier)
  3. Testes (specifically the seminiferous tubules, protected by the blood-testis barrier)
  4. Ovaries
  5. Pregnant uterus (fetus in particular)

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are incorrect. They are not immunologically privileged sites

questions.text: The following image depicts :
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Production of monoclonal antibodies:

  • Image depicting the process shown, which is the production of monoclonal antibodies
  • Monoclonal antibodies are antibodies that are produced against an antigen with single epitope that stimulates only single clone of B cells, known as hybridoma cells.

The image likely represents the steps involved in the hybridoma technology, which is a widely used method for generating monoclonal antibodies. This process typically includes the following steps:

  1. Immunization: An animal, such as a mouse, is immunized with the target antigen to stimulate the production of specific antibodies by B cells.
  2. Harvesting antibody-producing cells: Antibody-producing cells, specifically the B cells, are isolated from the immunized animal, typically from the spleen or lymph nodes.
  3. Fusion: The isolated B cells are fused with myeloma cells, which are immortal tumor cells. This fusion creates hybridoma cells that possess the ability to produce antibodies indefinitely.
  4. Screening and selection: The hybridoma cells are screened and selected based on their ability to produce the desired antibody. This involves testing the specificity and affinity of the antibodies produced by different hybridoma clones.
  5. Cloning: Selected hybridoma cells are cloned to obtain pure and stable cell lines, ensuring the consistent production of the desired monoclonal antibody.
  6. Antibody production: The established hybridoma cell lines are cultured in the laboratory to produce large quantities of the specific monoclonal antibody.

Incorrect Option:

Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option A for an explanation.

questions.text: N. meningitidis can be caused by deficiency of ........... ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - C5-C9 Deficiency:

  • Neisseria meningitidis is a bacterium that can cause meningococcal meningitis. The complement system plays an important role in the immune response against N. meningitidis. Specifically, the deficiency of the terminal complement components C5-C9 increases the susceptibility to infections caused by this bacterium.
  • Deficiency of the complement components C5-C9, also known as the membrane attack complex (MAC), impairs the ability of the immune system to form the MAC and lyse bacterial cells.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - C1, C2, and C4 Deficiency: Deficiency of the complement components C1, C2, and C4 is associated with an increased susceptibility to systemic lupus erythematosus.

Option C - C3 Deficiency: C3 deficiency is a common complement deficiency associated with glomerulonephritis and pyogenic infections.

Option D - C1 Esterase Deficiency: C1 esterase deficiency leads to overactivity of the classical pathway leading to Hereditary angioneurotic edema.

questions.text: Anaphylaxis occurred in a boy who was eating peanut butter. This scenario exemplifies:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - IgE-Mediated Reaction:

  • Anaphylaxis is a Type 1 hypersensitivity reaction/IgE-mediated hypersensitivity reaction.
  • In response to the allergic food, the immune system produces large amounts of IgE antibodies that bind to mast cells and basophils. This triggers the release of histamine and other inflammatory mediators that cause the symptoms of anaphylaxis.

  • This reaction occurs in 2 phases:
    • Sensitization Phase
    • Effector Phase
  • Sensitization Phase:
    • Allergen is processed by APC & peptides of it are presented to CD4 T-cells → activates TH cells → IL4 is released → activates B cells → IgE production → homocytotropism (movement towards the mast cells) and sensitize the mast cells.
  • Effector Phase:
    • Same allergen presented second time → Mast cell degranulation → Primary and secondary mediators.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - T Cell-Mediated Cytotoxicity: It is a type 4 hypersensitivity reaction, for example, Mantoux test and multiple sclerosis.

Option C - IgG-Mediated Reaction: IgG-mediated reactions are seen in type 2 hypersensitivity reactions, for example, Rh incompatibility and blood transfusion reactions. 

Option D - Antigen-Antibody Complex Mediated: It is a type 3 hypersensitivity reaction, for example, Systemic lupus erythematosus and Henoch schonlein purpura.

questions.text: In a case of chronic allergy, which immunoglobulin demonstrates increased levels?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - IgE:

  • IgE is the immunoglobulin that plays a central role in allergic reactions. It is responsible for triggering the release of histamine and other inflammatory substances in response to an allergen. Elevated levels of IgE are commonly seen in individuals with chronic allergies and are associated with conditions like allergic rhinitis, asthma, and atopic dermatitis.

Incorrect Option:

Option A - IgA: IgA is primarily involved in local or mucosal immunityand provides protection against pathogens by cross-linking bigger antigens with multiple epitopes and preventing entry through mucosal surface.

Option B - IgM: IgM is the first antibody produced in response to an infection and is the most potent activator of complement pathway.

Option D - IgG: IgG provides immunity to the fetus and newborn, mediates precipitation and neutralization reactions, and activates complement pathway.
